title: 109_hr5892
content: The "Farmers Tax Deferral Act" allows for the nontaxable exchange of qualified agricultural property for real property under section 1046 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. No gain or loss recognized for qualified person receiving US real property in exchange for qualified agricultural property. Qualified person defined as individual age 55+, corporation owned by individuals age 55+, or partnership/trust/estate owned by individuals age 55+. Qualified agricultural property includes agricultural structures in service for over 20 years. The term 'agricultural property' includes structures in service for over 20 years and related real property, equipment, or fixtures. 'United States real property' refers to real property located in the United States. Property must be identified and exchanged within 180 days to qualify. Taxpayer must identify property for exchange within 45 days of transferring relinquished property. Property received must be within 180 days or by the due date of the tax return. Rules regarding basis, exchanges not solely in kind, and related parties apply. Transaction described is treated as a Section 1031 exchange for tax purposes. Rules similar to section 1031 apply for exchanges of qualified agricultural property. Gain from the disposition of such property is not recognized under section 1046, limiting the amount of gain taken into account by the transferor. If property is disposed of without recognizing gain under section 1046, the transferor's gain is limited to the sum of recognized gain on the disposition and the fair market value of property acquired that is not section 1245 property or US real property. If US real property acquired in an exchange under section 1046 is sold by the transferee, the lesser of the gain or ordinary income recapture applies. If US real property acquired in an exchange under section 1046 is disposed of by the transferee, the ordinary income recapture applies on the excess of the amount realized over the adjusted basis of the property. The adjusted basis of real property or the excess of gain treated as ordinary income under this section shall be recognized as ordinary income, effective immediately. The amendments made by this Act treat gain on the disposition of qualified agricultural property as ordinary income, effective for transfers and dispositions after the enactment date. SEC. 3. SPECIAL RULES FOR INSTALLMENT SALES OF QUALIFIED AGRICULTURAL PROPERTY. Special rule for qualified agricultural property under section 453 of the Internal Revenue Code allows income from installment sales to be recognized as recapture income in the same proportion as aggregate recapture income. The amendments made by this section apply to sales after the enactment date.
